name: Surface area and volume of prisms method selection 1

skills.name: Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units
Calculate the volume of a cuboid when the dimensions are given in the same units
Calculate the volume of a triangular-based prism when the dimensions are given in the same units
Identify a prism from a diagram

explanations.A: Here we have multiplied all of the numbers together. We should only include 3 once.
explanations.B: Not quite! This is a correct possible method. Multiplying by 4 and then dividing by 2 is the same as multiplying by 2, so even though this isn't the most straightforward way of calculating the volume, it would work.
explanations.C: Not quite! This is how we calculate the volume of a cuboid: length x width x height.
explanations.D: Not quite! This is a correct possible method. Multiplying by 2 and by 5 is the same as multiplying by 10, so even though this isn't the most obvious way of calculating the volume, it would work.

explanations.A: Not quite! This is how we calculate the volume of a cuboid: length x width x height.
explanations.B: Not quite! This is a correct possible method. Multiplying by 6 and then dividing by 2 is the same as multiplying by 3, so even though this isn't the most straightforward way of calculating the volume, it would work.
explanations.C: Not quite! This is a correct possible method. Multiplying by 2 and by 4 is the same as multiplying by 8, so even though this isn't the most obvious way of calculating the volume, it would work.
explanations.D: Here all of the dimensions have been multiplied together, but the 4 has been incorrectly multiplied twice.

explanations.A: The volume of a cube or cuboid is length × width × height. Calculate each volume first then pick the odd one out.
explanations.B: The volume of a cube or cuboid is length × width × height. Calculate each volume first then pick the odd one out.
explanations.C: The volume of a cube or cuboid is length × width × height. Calculate each volume first then pick the odd one out.
explanations.D: This cuboid has volume 8 × 2 × 2 = 32. The other shapes have a volume of 64.

explanations.A: The volume of a cube or cuboid is length × width × height. Calculate each volume first then pick the odd one out.
explanations.B: This cuboid has volume 1 × 16 × 2 = 32. The other shapes have a volume of 64.
explanations.C: The volume of a cube or cuboid is length × width × height. Calculate each volume first then pick the odd one out.
explanations.D: The volume of a cube or cuboid is length × width × height. Calculate each volume first then pick the odd one out.

explanations.A: This is a cylinder. A prism has two end faces that are identical and parallel to each other. A prism has no curved edges.
explanations.B: This is a sphere. A prism has two end faces that are identical and parallel to each other. A prism has no curved edges.
explanations.C: This is a pyramid. A prism has two end faces that are identical and parallel to each other. A prism has no curved edges.
explanations.D: A prism has two end faces that are identical and parallel to each other. A prism has only straight edges. Therefore none of these shapes are prisms.

explanations.A: This is a sphere. A prism has two end faces that are identical and parallel to each other. A prism has no curved edges.
explanations.B: This is a pyramid. A prism has two end faces that are identical and parallel to each other.
explanations.C: This is a prism, as it has two identical end faces that are parallel to each other. The cross-section of this shape is the same all along its length.
explanations.D: This is a cone. A prism has two end faces that are identical and parallel to each other.

explanations.A: I think you have calculated the volume. The surface area is the total area of all six rectangular faces.
explanations.B: I think you have only calculated the surface area of the three faces you can see. What about the other three faces?
explanations.C: Not quite. The surface area is the total area of all six rectangular faces.
explanations.D: The total area of the six rectangular faces is 2(2×5 + 2×10 + 10×5) = 160 cm².

explanations.A: I think you have only calculated the surface area of the three faces you can see. What about the other three faces?
explanations.B: Not quite. The surface area is the total area of all six rectangular faces.
explanations.C: The total area of the six rectangular faces is 2(3×6 + 3×12 + 12×6) = 252 cm².
explanations.D: I think you have calculated the volume. The surface area is the total area of all six rectangular faces.

explanations.A: Don't forget to divide by 2 when you are calculating the area of the front triangular face.
explanations.B: I think you have just added together the lengths you can see. The volume of a prism is the area of the cross section (in this case the triangle) multiplied by the length.
explanations.C: The volume of a prism is the area of the cross section (in this case the triangle) multiplied by the length. (½ × 6 × 2) × 12 = 72 cm³.
explanations.D: There is enough information. The volume of a prism is the area of the cross section (in this case the triangle) multiplied by the length.

explanations.A: Don't forget to divide by 2 when you are calculating the area of the front triangular face.
explanations.B: The volume of a prism is the area of the cross section (in this case the triangle) multiplied by the length. (½ × 8 × 3) × 10 = 120 cm³.
explanations.C: I think you have just added together the lengths you can see. The volume of a prism is the area of the cross section (in this case the triangle) multiplied by the length.
explanations.D: There is enough information. The volume of a prism is the area of the cross section (in this case the triangle) multiplied by the length.
